text: Hi, this is Julián from MinuteEarth.

Sharks are known for their teeth...not their
scales.

But shark scales have a lot more in common
with their teeth - and yours - than you might
think.

Those tiny rough bumps are called “denticles”,
from the same root as “dental” and “dentist”.

And just like our mouth denticles - I mean,
our teeth - they have a soft, pulpy center

surrounded by hard tissue called dentin and
are capped with shiny enamel.

But what *do* shark scales have to do with
teeth?

To answer that, we have to take a journey
back in time before any of our vertebrate
ancestors had teeth or scales.

The earliest vertebrates were primitive fish
that took in water through their open, toothless
mouths and filtered out food.

And their small, scale-less bodies left them
defenseless against the giant predatory invertebrates
that lived at the time.

But eventually, the skin tissue on some of
these fishes evolved into protective, rigid
armor around their heads.
But the rest of their bodies were still squishy.

So the fishes’ head armor ended up separating
into smaller scales that covered their entire
bodies - voila, protection and flexibility.

These flexible, scale-y fish were better off
than their predecessors, but they were still

nowhere near becoming apex predators themselves
- they were still stuck passively filtering
tiny tasty tidbits out of the water.

Scientists think the next evolutionary leap
involved scales around some fishes’ mouths

migrating inward, going from teeth-like to
just teeth.

But teeth aren't all that useful without a
way to move them around, so it also took the

evolution of jaws to turn mouth scales into
weapons.

Large prey was now on the menu; fish could
use their jaws to clamp down on prey and their
teeth to slice it into chunks.

These toothy fish gave rise to modern sharks,
which eventually dominated the oceans.

Toothy fish were also the predecessors to
the first vertebrates to crawl up on land.

These vertebrates - and their mouthparts - quickly
diversified.

Some new landlubbers developed the ability
to chew – to manipulate their teeth and
jaws to grind their food into small pieces.

Compared to animals that swallowed chunks
of food whole, chewers could digest those

small pieces more quickly and more completely,
saving them energy and extracting more nutrients.
Teeth specialized too.

Herbivores evolved incisors in the front to
slice through fibrous plants and broader,
flatter teeth in the back to grind them up.

Carnivores got long and sharp teeth for catching
and tearing up prey, and omnivores (like us)
ended up with a bit of everything.

And as far as we can tell, all these teeth
came from the very same ancestral scales that
evolved into modern shark scales.

I guess in a roundabout way, sharks’ scales
are their most famous feature, if tooth be
told.

We’re actually on a bit of a tooth kick
these days.

We recently launched the second season of
our show MinuteBody, and the newest episode
is all about teeth!

You can check it out exclusively on Nebula,
a platform built by independent education-y

creators like us as a place to experiment
and try out new ideas.

And since our favorite documentary streaming
service, CuriosityStream, loves supporting

new creators, they've teamed up with Nebula
to help us launch the new season of MinuteBody.

As part of our partnership, when you sign
up for CuriosityStream at curiositystream.com/minuteearth,
you’ll also get Nebula for free.

So for just fifteen bucks a year - literally
just over a dollar a month - you'll not only

get access to CuriosityStream's huge library
of high-quality content like "Out Of The Cradle"

and “Ancient Oceans”, you’ll also get
free access to tons of creative stuff on Nebula

from the folks behind TierZoo, Polyphonic,
Wendover - and all-new episodes of MinuteBody.

We think you’ll really be able to sink your
teeth into it.
